text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-page miniature within a simple ruled border, no accompanying text on this folio, image occupies entire page space.

color_scheme.color_usage: Blue reserved for the celestial realm with silver and red stars; brown earth tone for ground to contrast divine act; green waves for living waters; red and blue robes for divine figure; white used in highlights to model flesh and vegetation; pigments remain vibrant with minimal fading, silver stars showing slight tarnish.

features: God larger and standing above Adam to denote supremacy
Diagonal axis from God’s raised hand down to reclining Adam
Horizontal placement of Adam contrasting verticality of God
Eve positioned at intersection of diagonal and horizontal axes
Lower register of animals forming a continuous base

decorative_elements: Starry sky band with alternating silver and red stars
Simple painted border with blue and red bands

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work in brown ink with consistent line weight
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color application with minimal hatching and selective white highlighting
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Overlapping figures and registers without linear perspective, scale based on importance rather than spatial depth

content_theme.scene_description: The miniature depicts the Creation of Eve from Adam’s rib (Genesis 2), with God the Creator standing left of center, clad in a red-lined blue robe and haloed, his right hand raised in blessing and left hand holding Eve’s hand. Eve, nude and partially formed, emerges upright from Adam’s side, her long hair cascading. Adam reclines horizontally on a rocky outcrop at right, nude, his head propped on his right hand in a soporific pose. The figures occupy a richly painted brown ground. Two tall stylized flowering plants flank the Creator and the primeval couple: on the left, pale pink and blue blossoms; on the right, a large artichoke-like blossom with blue petals. Below, undulating green waves populated by fish and waterfowl form the lower register. To either side of Adam’s feet, terrestrial animals—goat, ram, donkey and a red-headed creature—peer into the scene, symbolizing animal creation. The sky band at top is rendered in deep azure with silver and red stars and a crescent moon. Spatially, God is scaled slightly larger than Adam and Eve to indicate hierarchy, and overlapping registers of earth and water denote zones of creation.

religious: God the Creator as bearded haloed figure in red-lined blue robe
Adam reclining nude on rocky outcrop, head supported by hand
Eve nude, emerging from Adam’s side, long hair flowing

natural: Stylized flowering plants with pink and blue blooms
Undulating green waves with fish and waterfowl
Terrestrial animals (goat, ram, donkey, red-headed beast)

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum with smooth, well-pumiced surface and visible subtle hair follicle pattern typical of 13th-century French manuscripts
technical_features.preservation_condition: Well-preserved pigments with minimal fading; silver stars slightly tarnished; minor surface abrasion at margins
notable_physical_characteristics: Fine iron-gall ink underdrawing visible under UV
Flat color application with selective white highlighting
Silver paint for stars with slight tarnish

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This high-quality miniature of the Creation of Eve likely originates from a 13th-century French workshop, possibly for a Bible moralisee or luxury psalter. The absence of accompanying text on the folio and the refined execution suggest it was a standalone full-page illustration commissioned by a noble patron. The starry azure band recalls the dazzling celestial motifs of Parisian illuminators during the reign of Louis IX, while the naturalistic yet stylized flora and fauna reflect an interest in the full spectrum of God’s creation. The hierarchical scaling of God over Adam and Eve adheres to orthodox iconographic conventions, while the diagonal composition introduces dynamic movement, aligning with innovative practices in Gothic illumination. Technically, the use of verdigris green, vermillion red, and deep brown earth pigment, complemented by silver-paint stars, demonstrates sophisticated knowledge of pigment layering and metalpoint techniques. Iconographically, the inclusion of both terrestrial beasts and aquatic creatures underscores a comprehensive theology of creation, uniting Old Testament narrative with a visual taxonomy of life. Comparative analysis shows affinities with the English Channel School in the limp modeling of flesh and the use of flat color fields. Yet the precise underdrawing and crisp outlines signal a Parisian origin. This sheet exemplifies the fusion of tradition and innovation characteristic of high Gothic book production, serving both didactic and devotional functions for an elite audience.
